<\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-eric-rich\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> ERIC RICHARD HUYETT<\/span> on Mar 17, 2020\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-on-the-desired-host-\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <p>On the desired host as root, run 'dsmc'<\/p><ul><li>q fi (query what directories are backed up)<\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">q ba \/&lt;from above&gt;\/&lt;path&gt;\/* (query what files are backed up)<\/span><ul><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-subdir=yes (include&nbsp;<\/span>subdirectories)<\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-inactive (include deleted files and older versions)<\/span><\/li><li><span>-pitd=x\/x\/x (point in time date)<\/span><\/li><li><span>-pitt=x:x:x (point in time time)<\/span><\/li><\/ul><\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">rest &lt;what&gt; &lt;destination&gt; (what would be from query above)<\/span><ul><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-subdir=yes&nbsp;<\/span><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">(include&nbsp;<\/span><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">subdirectories)<\/span><\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-inactive&nbsp;<span>(include deleted files and older versions)<\/span><\/span><\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-pitd=x\/x\/x&nbsp;<span>(point in time date)<\/span><\/span><\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-pitt=x:x:x&nbsp;<span>(point in time time)<\/span><\/span><\/li><li><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0.0px;\">-pick (interactively select files to restore)<\/span><\/li><\/ul><\/li><\/ul>\n                    <\/div>\n\n                                        \n Title is blank after consecutive number removal...Auto-Title applied: Operations Team : (a) Steps Used to Install Open OnDemandstring(7191) "{"id":2666,"book_id":107,"chapter_id":0,"name":"Operations Team : (a) Steps Used to Install Open OnDemand","slug":"operations-team-a-steps-used-to-install-open-ondemand-w4e","html":"\n\n    \n        <title id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-%28a\">Operations Team : (a) Steps Used to Install Open OnDemand<\/title>\n        <link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"styles\/site.css\" type=\"text\/css\" id=\"bkmrk-\">\n        <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text\/html; charset=UTF-8\" id=\"bkmrk--1\">\n    \n\n    \n        <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper\">\n            <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-1\" class=\"aui-page-panel\">\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-2\">\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-3\">\n                        <ol id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-4\">\n                            <li class=\"first\">\n                                <span><a href=\"index.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Team_1638637.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Open-OnDemand-Installation-and-Testing_92799790.html\">Open OnDemand Installation and Testing<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-%28a-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-%28a-2\">\n                            Operations Team : (a) Steps Used to Install Open OnDemand\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-robert-sa\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> Robert Sand<\/span>, last modified on Dec 28, 2021\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-subscription-manager\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <ul><li><pre>subscription-manager repos --enable<span class=\"o\">=<\/span>rhel-server-rhscl-7-rpms<\/pre><\/li><li><pre>yum install <a href=\"https:\/\/yum.osc.edu\/ondemand\/2.0\/ondemand-release-web-2.0-1.noarch.rpm\" class=\"external-link\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:\/\/yum.osc.edu\/ondemand\/2.0\/ondemand-release-web-2.0-1.noarch.rpm<\/a><\/pre><\/li><li><pre><code>yum install httpd24<\/code><\/pre><\/li><li><code>yum install rh-ruby27<\/code><\/li><li><code>yum install rh-nodejs10<\/code><\/li><li><code>systemctl start httpd24-httpd<\/code><\/li><li><code>vi \/etc\/yum\/pluginconf.d\/search-disabled-repos.conf :: change notify-only=1 to notify-only=0<br><\/code><\/li><li>yum install ondemand&nbsp; :: tell it to search disabled repos<\/li><li>httpd24-mod_auth_openidc&nbsp; (make sure this is done before puppet goes through and removes the ondemand repo if it does use reinstall on second step)<\/li><\/ul><p>RedHat 8 already has the httpd24 apache 2.4 web server installed as the main web server in \/etc\/httpd.&nbsp; Below is what is needed to get ruby, nodejs, and ondemand installed:<\/p><ul><li><pre>dnf module <span class=\"nb\">enable<\/span> ruby:2.7<br>dnf module <span class=\"nb\">enable<\/span> nodejs:12<\/pre><\/li><li>The rest of the packages needed by ondemand are in the codeready-builder-for-rhel-8-x86_64-rpms<\/li><li><pre>yum install https:\/\/yum.osc.edu\/ondemand\/2.0\/ondemand-release-web-2.0-1.noarch.rpm<\/pre><\/li><li><pre>yum install ondemand<\/pre><\/li><\/ul><p>The above commands will install all software needed by ondemand.&nbsp; The rest of the documentation follows as is except where paths to the web server is involved.<\/p><p>The next steps are to configure webaccess for login authentication.<\/p><ul><li>yum install gcc openssl-devel&nbsp; libtool<\/li><li>create an ssl certificate using a certificate authority (not self signed) we need the servername.cer, servername_interm.cer and the servername.key files<\/li><li><p><br><\/p><\/li><li>Configure openid-connect after requesting the system be added to cilogon.<\/li><\/ul><div class=\"code panel pdl\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"codeContent panelContent pdl\">\n<pre class=\"syntaxhighlighter-pre\" data-syntaxhighlighter-params=\"brush: java; gutter: false; theme: Confluence\" data-theme=\"Confluence\">     auth:\n       - \"AuthType openid-connect\"\n       - \"Require valid-user\"\n\n# Use OIDC logout\n# logout_redirect: \"\/oidc?logout=https%3A%2F%ondemand.example.com\"\n\n# Capture system user name from authenticated user name\n#     user_map_cmd: \"\/opt\/ood\/ood_auth_map\/bin\/ood_auth_map.regex --regex='^(\\\\w+)@psu.edu'\"user_map_match: '^([^@]+)@.*$'\n     user_map_match: '^([^@]+)@.*$'\n\n     oidc_uri: \"\/oidc\/redirect\"\n     oidc_provider_metadata_url: \"https:\/\/cilogon.org\/.well-known\/openid-configuration\"\n     oidc_client_id: \"&lt;client id from registration with cilogon\"\n     oidc_client_secret: \"&lt;secret from regisration with cilogon\"\n     oidc_remote_user_claim: \"eppn\"\n     oidc_scope: \"openid profile email org.cilogon.userinfo\"\n     oidc_session_inactivity_timeout: 28800\n     oidc_session_max_duration: 28800\n     oidc_state_max_number_of_cookies: \"10 true\"\n     oidc_settings:\n       OIDCPassIDTokenAs: \"serialized\"\n       OIDCPassRefreshToken: \"On\"\n       OIDCPassClaimsAs: \"environment\"\n       OIDCStripCookies: \"mod_auth_openidc_session mod_auth_openidc_session_chunks mod_auth_openidc_session_0 mod_auth_openidc_session_1\"<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><p>Create&nbsp;&nbsp; Crypto Passphrase with: '<code class=\"java plain\">openssl rand -base64 <\/code><code class=\"java value\">24' --<\/code> and add to the \/opt\/rh\/httpd24\/root\/etc\/httpd\/conf.d\/auth_openidc.conf file under mandatory items at top of conf file.<\/p><ul><li>start the web server 'systemctl start class=\"confluenceTd\">comp-mgc-0008<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">Dell DSS 8440<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">16<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">T4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">gc_t4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">mgc_nih<\/td><\/tr><tr><td class=\"confluenceTd\">comp-mgc-0009<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">Dell DSS 8440<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">16<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">T4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">gc_t4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">mgc_nih<\/td><\/tr><tr><td class=\"confluenceTd\">comp-mgc-0010<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">Dell DSS 8440<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">16<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">T4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">gc_t4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">mgc_nih<\/td><\/tr><tr><td class=\"confluenceTd\">comp-mgc-0011<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">Dell DSS 8440<\/td><td class=\"confluenceTd\">16<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">T4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">gc_t4<\/td><td colspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">mgc_nih<\/td><\/tr><\/tbody><\/table><\/div><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">To submit to any of the nodes from the NIH portion, you can do something like:<\/p><div class=\"code panel pdl\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"codeContent panelContent pdl\">\n<pre class=\"syntaxhighlighter-pre\" data-syntaxhighlighter-params=\"brush: text; gutter: false; theme: Confluence\" data-theme=\"Confluence\">$ qsub -I -l qos=mgc_nih -l nodes=1:ppn=4:gpus=2  -l walltime=24:00:00 -A mgc_nih<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">To submit to the NIH nodes, you would submit with mgc_nih for both the account and qos parameters.<\/p><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">In addition there is an \"open\" qos for suspendable jobs that can run across all nodes.&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p><h2 class=\"auto-cursor-target\" id=\"bkmrk-mri-accounts\">MRI accounts<\/h2><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Doug Cowen wanted to be able to track usage by account, so we've implemented some accounts based on the groups below for the MRI groups.<\/p><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Users should submit to an account like: acv13_mri rather than to the generic mgc_mri account.<\/p><h2 class=\"auto-cursor-target\" id=\"bkmrk-adding-users-to-the-\">Adding Users to the MGC cluster&nbsp;<\/h2><p>This is set-up similar to how Cyberlamp has been managed.&nbsp; Users will need to be approved by the PI's above<\/p><p>Users should be added to a subgroup belonging to a PI group.&nbsp; Each user is assigned to a group based on the PI they're working with:<\/p><p>MRI groups:&nbsp;acv13_mgc_mri_collab, cxs1024_mgc_mri_collab, dfc13_mgc_mri_collab, guc18_mgc_mri_collab,&nbsp;mmg62_mgc_mri_collab eor_mgc_mri_collab<\/p><p>Each of these groups has a corresponding \"account\" defined in Moab as: acv13_mri, cxs1024_mri, dfc13_mri, guc18_mri, mmg62_mri.&nbsp; Users will need to submit to one of these accounts if they plan to run jobs on the comp-mgc nodes<\/p><p>Each of these groups belongs to the overall mgc_mri_collab group<\/p><p>NIH groups:&nbsp;epo2_mgc_nih_collab, nxd338_mgc_nih_collab<\/p><p>Each of these groups belongs to the overall mgc_nih_collab group<\/p><p>Both the mgc_nih_collab group and the mgc_mri_collab group belong to the overall mgc_collab group.<\/p><p>If a user is added to one of these groups, the hostdgroups script will need to be run on moab01 to enable them to submit\/run jobs:<\/p><div class=\"table-wrap\"><table class=\"wrapped confluenceTable\" style=\"text-align: left;\"><colgroup><col><\/colgroup><tbody style=\"text-align: left;\"><tr style=\"text-align: left;\"><td style=\"text-align: left;\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><code class=\"bash comments\" style=\"text-align: left;\"># \/opt\/moab\/tools\/DailyHostedUpdate.py<\/code><\/p><\/td><\/tr><\/tbody><\/table><\/div><p><br><\/p><p><br><\/p><p><br><\/p>\n                    <\/div>\n\n Groups\/...\/file system The whole way up to end user available space<\/li><li>Live evacuation of hardware devices from file systems.&nbsp; Including disks\/RAID Groups\/etc.\/NSD Equivalent<\/li><li>Filesets or equivalent to which policy can be applied<\/li><li>Quotas on users and Filesets or directory trees<\/li><li>Can be optimized for large and\/or small files<ul><li>Increasing inodes on a live filesystem<\/li><\/ul><\/li><li>Snapshots<\/li><li>File permission and ACLs&nbsp;<\/li><li>SMB\/Windows access to files<\/li><li>Ethernet and IB connections<\/li><li>NFS export&nbsp;<\/li><li>User and Groups from RedHat Identity Management (IPA\/LDAP)<ul><li>What about nested groups<\/li><\/ul><\/li><li>Incremental backups (like with TSM) without needing periodic \"Full\" backups<\/li><li>Auto-expire old files from \"scratch\"&nbsp;<\/li><li>How do file locks work and what are the trade-offs with performance<\/li><\/ul><p><br><\/p>\n                   <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-cr-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-cr-2\">\n                            Operations Team : Creating Compute Allocation [OUTDATED]\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-myles-r-g\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> MYLES R GOODWIN<\/span>, last modified on Apr 26, 2021\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-this-is-meant-to-be-\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <p>This is meant to be a quick set of steps to create a compute allocation on ACI.&nbsp; For a more detailed explanation, please see <a href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/IT\/Adding+an+ACI+2.0+Compute+Allocation\">Adding an ACI 2.0 Compute Allocation<\/a><\/p><p>Node types available are<span style=\"color: rgb(255,0,0);\"><strong> bc, gc, hc, lc<\/strong><\/span>, and <span style=\"color: rgb(255,0,0);\"><strong>sc<\/strong><\/span><\/p><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-information\"><span class=\"aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-info confluence-information-macro-icon\"><\/span><div class=\"confluence-information-macro-body\"><pre>Node features are as follows:<\/pre><pre>Basic (bc) = 'basic'<\/pre><pre>Standard (sc) = 'stmem'<\/pre><pre>High Memory (hc) = 'himem'<\/pre><pre>GPUs k80 (gc) = 'gc_k80'<\/pre><pre>GPUs p100 (gc) = 'gc_p100'<\/pre><pre>Legacy (lc) = 'legacy'<br>HPRC (vc) = 'vccore'<\/pre><\/div><\/div><h2 id=\"bkmrk-step-by-step-guide\">Step-by-step guide<\/h2><p><\/p><ol><li><pre>ssh ipa-utils01.int.aci.ics.psu.edu<\/pre><\/li><li><pre>kinit<\/pre><\/li><li>enter IPA Kerberos password<\/li><li><pre>Be a member of ops_collab<\/pre><\/li><li><pre>cd \/storage\/work\/mrg225\/allocStuff<\/pre><\/li><li>edit new CSV file that corresponds to the assigned JIRA task (e.g. vi SUPPORT-255_mjr79.csv)<ol><li>populate using the following format:<ol><li><strong><span style=\"color: rgb(255,0,0);\">PI_PSU_ID<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(51,153,102);\">SLAID<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(51,102,255);\">TRIAL-OR-GREAT<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(255,102,0);\">TYPE<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(0,128,128);\">FEATURE<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(255,0,255);\">NODECOUNT@CORES-PER-NODE<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(153,204,0);\">EXPIRATION (MM\/DD\/YYYY)<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(128,0,0);\">SUBALLOCATION NAME<\/span><\/strong><\/li><li><span style=\"color: rgb(255,0,0);\"><span style=\"color: rgb(0,0,0);\">e.g.&nbsp;<\/span> <strong>mjr79<\/strong><\/span><strong>,<span style=\"color: rgb(51,153,102);\">a<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(51,102,255);\">g<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(255,102,0);\">bc<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(0,128,128);\">basic<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(255,0,255);\">3@10<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(153,204,0);\">06\/17\/2019<\/span>,<span style=\"color: rgb(128,0,0);\">default<\/span><\/strong><strong><span style=\"color: rgb(128,0,0);\"><br><\/span><\/strong><\/li><\/ol><\/li><li><span style=\"color: rgb(128,0,0);\"><span style=\"color: rgb(0,0,0);\">Script will add all user's of PI's current collab group to the allocation<\/span><\/span><\/li><\/ol><\/li><li><span style=\"color: rgb(128,0,0);\"><span style=\"color: rgb(0,0,0);\">create compute allocation by running script and supplying it with the CSV file created in step 6<\/span><\/span><ol><li><pre>.\/create_allocations_v2-ipa-utils01.sh SUPPORT-255_mjr79.csv<span style=\"color: rgb(128,0,0);\"><span style=\"color: rgb(0,0,0);\"><br><\/span><\/span><\/pre><\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-information\"><p class=\"title\">Example CSV file containing ALL possible allocation types<\/p><span class=\"aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-info confluence-information-macro-icon\"><\/span><div class=\"confluence-information-macro-body\"><pre>abc123,a,t,bc,basic,1@20,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,t,sc,stmem,1@20,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,t,hc,himem,1@40,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,t,lc,legacy,1@20,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,t,gc,gc_k80,1@24,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,t,gc,gc_p100,1@24,01\/01\/2020,default<br>abc123,a,t,vc,vccore,1@1,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,g,bc,basic,1@20,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,g,sc,stmem,1@20,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,g,hc,himem,1@40,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,g,lc,legacy,1@20,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,g,gc,gc_k80,1@24,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><pre>abc123,a,g,gc,gc_p100,1@24,01\/01\/2020,default<br>abc123,a,g,vc,vccore,1@1,01\/01\/2020,default<\/pre><\/div><\/div><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-information\"><p class=\"title\">IPA output of compute allocation creation<\/p><span class=\"aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-info confluence-information-macro-icon\"><\/span><div class=\"confluence-information-macro-body\"><p>Using the example above, output should look like this:<\/p><p><br><\/p><pre>creating mjr79_a_g_bc_default group\n----------------------------------\nAdded group \"mjr79_a_g_bc_default\"\n----------------------------------\n Group name: mjr79_a_g_bc_default\n Description: mjr79_a_g_bc_default\n GID: 13359\n ACI Node Features (himem|ivybridge): basic\n ACI Core Allocation (&lt;nnodes&gt;@&lt;ncores&gt;: 3@10:06\/17\/2019\nadding mjr79_collab members to mjr79_a_g_bc_default\n Group name: mjr79_a_g_bc_default\n Description: mjr79_a_g_bc_default\n GID: 13359\n ACI Node Features (himem|ivybridge): basic\n ACI Core Allocation (&lt;nnodes&gt;@&lt;ncores&gt;: 3@10:06\/17\/2019\n Member users: mjr79\n-------------------------\nNumber of members added 1\n-------------------------<\/pre><\/div><\/div><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-information\"><p class=\"title\">Verify Allocation availability<\/p><span class=\"aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-info confluence-information-macro-icon\"><\/span><div class=\"confluence-information-macro-body\"><p>From anywhere one can run mam-list-accounts, run the following to verify the availability of the allocation created above:<\/p><pre><br>[mrg225@aci-lgn-001 ~]$ sudo `which mam-list-accounts` -a mjr79_a_g_bc_default\nName Active CoreAllocation NodeFeatures \n-------------------- ------ --------------- ------------ \nmjr79_a_g_bc_default True 3@10:06\/17\/2019 basic \n[mrg225@aci-lgn-001 ~]$ <\/pre><\/div><\/div><h2 id=\"bkmrk-hprc-example\">HPRC Example<\/h2><p>Using the above-mentioned nomenclature, this would be an example of an HPRC allocation for 2000 virtual cores:<\/p><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-information\"><p mam-list-accounts` -a $I; done\nName Active CoreAllocation NodeFeatures \n------------------- ------ ----------------- ------------ \nixd4_i_g_vc_default True 2000@1:10\/15\/2019 vccore allocations.&nbsp; Which is \"correct\" or are they both good?<\/p><p>Why is this update with the CSV file \"better\" than just typing stuff on the command line without the CSV?<\/p><p><br><\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n class=\"smallfont\"><p>Fewer keystrokes = less chance for error.&nbsp; Having CSVs that correspond with a specific JIRA ticket are a good insurance policy in the event of a catastrophic loss.<\/p><p><br><\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n                                        <img src=\"images\/icons\/contenttypes\/comment_16.png\" height=\"16\" width=\"16\" border=\"0\" align=\"absmiddle\">\n                                        Posted by mrg225 at Sep 04, 2018                      <td style=\"border-top: 1px dashed #666666\">\n                                    <a name=\"comment-18223556\"><\/a>\n                                    <font class=\"smallfont\"><p>I'm not buying the fewer keystrokes thing.&nbsp; You have to type them into the csv file or on the command line.&nbsp; Either way they have to show up somewhere.<\/p><p>I agree with the point of having something to look back at.&nbsp; The CSV files give us that.&nbsp; I'd prefer a better option, I don't have one yet though.<\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n                                        <img src=\"images\/icons\/contenttypes\/comment_16.png\" approach is less preferable to relying on shell histories or manual data entry?&nbsp; At this point there are CSVs for himem, stmem, and basic which require minor editing when creating a new allocation.&nbsp; Granted, it's not a completely automated process yet, but I haven't heard any complaints yet from anybody else who routinely creates compute allocations.<\/p><\/font>\n        <td style=\"border-top: 1px dashed #666666\">\n                                    <a name=\"comment-18223560\"><\/a>\n                                    <font class=\"smallfont\"><p>Hmm...&nbsp; I didn't think that's what I was saying.&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p><p>I meant to say that the argument for \"less keystrokes = less chance for error\" wasn't convincing.&nbsp; That does not imply that command line is less error prone or better.&nbsp;I'm not suggesting that you change anything about what you're currently doing.&nbsp; I'm trying to understand the process and why we have differences in the documentation.<\/p><p>I agree that the CSV files give us a kind of history which is LOTS better than multiple bash history files from multiple people.<\/p><p>I DID mean to say that I don't think the CSV file method is ideal.&nbsp; I don't have anything better right now.&nbsp; I'm not advocating abandoning what we have, until there's something better.&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p><p>I don't understand the comment just now about \"there are CSVs for himem, stmem and basic\"&nbsp; I didn't see that from the documentation above.&nbsp; I see that we're supposed to create a CSV file with a ticket number.&nbsp; In the allocStuff directory there are several SUPPORT-XXX_username.csv files.&nbsp; That matches the above documentation.&nbsp; There are also lots of username*.csv files, it's not clear what those are for or why they didn't get the SUPPORT-XXX type filenames.<\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n                                        <img src=\"images\/icons\/contenttypes\/comment_16.png\" height=\"16\" width=\"16\" border=\"0\" align=\"absmiddle\">\n                                        Posted by gbs35 at Sep 05, 2018 12:53\n                                    <\/div>\n                                <\/td>\n                            <\/tr>\n                                                        <tr>\n                                <td style=\"border-top: 1px dashed #666666\">\n                                    <a name=\"comment-18223568\"><\/a>\n                                    <font class=\"smallfont\"><p>That was something I started doing back in June to make it more readily identifiable, which the above documentation reflects.&nbsp; One thing I could look to implement would be to include the JIRA ticket (e.g. SUPPORT-588) in the description of the IPA group being created.&nbsp; If one were to grep SUPPORT*.csv they'd find multiple instances of each core type (e.g. stmem, basic, himem).&nbsp; The only reason this is all in my work directory is due to \/gpfs\/group\/ops\/default\/scripts not being accessible from <a href=\"http:\/\/ipa-utils01.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\" class=\"external-link\" rel=\"nofollow\">ipa-utils01.int.aci.ics.psu.edu<\/a> as a mounted filesystem.<br><br>The CSV approach is a start, but is by no means a final end-state.&nbsp; It was a quick fix that made compute allocation creation easier, introduced some semblance of historical tracking, and provided a better means of backing up allocation creation histories.&nbsp; Down the road, I'd like to see some form of web front-end that <a class=\"confluence-userlink user-mention\" data-username=\"cra5108\" href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/~cra5108\" data-linked-resource-id=\"2589292\" data-linked-resource-version=\"2\" data-linked-resource-type=\"userinfo\" data-base-url=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\">C ROBIE AIKENS<\/a> could input compute allocation information to directly, have it stored in some type of auditable back-end, make the necessary changes to IPA, then periodically check with MAM to indicate whether the allocation exists or not...<\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n                                        <img src=\"images\/icons\/contenttypes\/comment_16.png\" height=\"16\" width=\"16\" border=\"0\" align=\"absmiddle\">\n                                        Posted by mrg225 at Sep 05, 2018 15:12\n                                    <\/div>\n                                <\/td>\n                            <\/tr>\n                                                        <tr>\n                                <td style=\"border-top: 1px dashed #666666\">\n                                    <a name=\"comment-18223662\"><\/a>\n                                    <font class=\"smallfont\"><p>As discussed with&nbsp;<a class=\"confluence-userlink user-mention\" data-username=\"gbs35\" href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/~gbs35\" data-linked-resource-id=\"18219310\" data-linked-resource-version=\"2\" data-linked-resource-type=\"userinfo\" data-base-url=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\">Gary Skouson<\/a>, I finally remembered the real reason for this CSV approach.&nbsp; It came about when I had to create 58 allocations as part of transitioning the various fairshare queues on LionXF and LionXG to ACI.&nbsp; This approach allowed them to be created, if memory serves, in about two and a half minutes once the master CSV was finalized.&nbsp; Figured I'd share this factoid in case anyone reading this were curious as to why this approach exists.<\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n Title contains numbers at the end: Updating Torque Builds 18225980
string(7263) "{"id":2676,"book_id":107,"chapter_id":0,"name":"Updating Torque Builds","slug":"updating-torque-builds-4RB","html":"\n\n    \n        <title id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-up\">Operations Team : Updating Torque Builds<\/title>\n        <link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"styles\/site.css\" type=\"text\/css\" id=\"bkmrk-\">\n        <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text\/html; charset=UTF-8\" id=\"bkmrk--1\">\n    \n\n    \n        <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper\">\n            <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-1\" class=\"aui-page-panel\">\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-2\">\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-3\">\n                        <ol id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-4\">\n                            <li class=\"first\">\n                                <span><a href=\"index.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Team_1638637.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Manual_18221242.html\">Operations Manual<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"PBS-info-in-support-space_18223096.html\">PBS info in support space<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-up-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-up-2\">\n                            Operations Team : Updating Torque Builds\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-adam-bren\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> ADAM BRENT FOCHT<\/span>, last modified by <span class=\"editor\"> Gary Skouson<\/span> on Mar 28, 2022\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-overviewtorque-is-de\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <h2 id=\"bkmrk-overview\">Overview<\/h2><p>Torque is deployed using RPMs built via the spec file contained in the <a href=\"https:\/\/bitbucket.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/projects\/INFRA\/repos\/torque-rpm\/browse?at=refs%2Fheads%2Fdevelopment\" class=\"external-link\" rel=\"nofollow\">torque-rpm git repo<\/a> on bitbucket.&nbsp; The production cluster (March 2022) is using the development branch of the code.<\/p><p>I took the stuff in the SOURCES and SPECS directories and copied them to my home dir under ~\/rpmbuild and also copied the&nbsp;torque-6.1.2.tar.gz package to SOURCES.<\/p><h2 id=\"bkmrk-conditional-builds\">Conditional Builds<\/h2><p>To build the Torque rpms, you'll want to be on a node with the nvidia stuff and you'll need the rpm-build package installed.&nbsp; The Turque build also depends on&nbsp;boost-devel and pam-devel, so you may need to install those too.<\/p><p>The rpm spec sets up a parametrized build based on spec conditionals.&nbsp; The available conditionals are:<\/p><ul><li>--with nvidia<\/li><li>--with<\/li><\/ul><p>I did:<\/p><div class=\"code panel pdl\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"codeContent panelContent pdl\">\n<pre class=\"syntaxhighlighter-pre\" data-syntaxhighlighter-params=\"brush: java; gutter: false; theme: Confluence\" data-theme=\"Confluence\">$ cd ~\/rpmbuild\/SPECS\n$ rpmbuild -ba moab-torque.spec\n.\n.\n.\n$ rpmbuild -ba --with nvidia moab-torque.spec\n.\n.\n.\n\n<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><p>That should produce two sets of RPMs in ~\/rpmbuild\/RPMS\/x86_64&nbsp; One set should have 'gpu' in the name.&nbsp; Those need to be in the repository for GPU nodes.&nbsp; The others are for the non-GPU nodes.<\/p><h2 id=\"bkmrk-torque-server-update\">Torque Server Updates (RHEL7)<\/h2><p>The rpmbuild tree for Torque builds (server and client\/mom) on RHEL7 resides on torque01.util.production.int.aci.ics.psu.edu in \/usr\/local\/src\/torque\/rpmbuild.<\/p><ol><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Update the spec file, generally to add a patch from Adaptive, being sure to increment the release value.&nbsp; An example from a recent git diff:<\/p><div class=\"code panel pdl\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"codeContent panelContent pdl\">\n<pre class=\"syntaxhighlighter-pre\" data-syntaxhighlighter-params=\"brush: text; gutter: false; theme: Confluence\" data-theme=\"Confluence\">$ git diff\ndiff --git a\/SPECS\/moab-torque.spec b\/SPECS\/moab-torque.spec\nindex bf1f5f1..e7511d3 100644\n--- a\/SPECS\/moab-torque.spec\n+++ b\/SPECS\/moab-torque.spec\n@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@\n %global pkg_name moab-torque\n %global pkg_ver 6.1.2\n-%global pkg_rls 5aci\n+%global pkg_rls 6aci\n %global pkg_summ Tera-scale Open-source Resource and QUEue manager\n %global pkg_desc TORQUE is an open source resource manager providing control over batch\\\n jobs and distributed compute nodes. It is a community effort based on\\\n@@ -101,6 +101,7 @@ Patch7:        TRQ-4047-memory-only-nodes.patch\n Patch8:        trq-4051.6111.loggingpatch.patch\n Patch9:        TRQ-4213.612.patch\n Patch10:       TRQ-4208.612.patch\n+Patch11:       trq-4250.612.patch3.txt\n %if 0%{?with_nvidia}\n AutoReq:   no\n %endif\n@@ -243,6 +244,7 @@ Development headers and libraries for TORQUE\n #%patch8 -p 1\n %patch9 -p 1\n %patch10 -p 1\n+%patch11 -p 1<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Prepare the commit, commit, and push to the remote repo:<\/p><div class=\"code panel pdl\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"codeContent panelContent pdl\">\n<pre class=\"syntaxhighlighter-pre\" data-syntaxhighlighter-params=\"brush: bash; gutter: false; theme: Confluence\" data-theme=\"Confluence\">$ git add SPECS\/moab-torque.spec SOURCES\/trq-4250.612.patch3.txt\n$ git commit -m 'Update for Adaptive case 26889 - errant job kills'\n$ git push<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n\n                                        \n                                                      \n                <\/div>             <\/div> \n            <div id=\"bkmrk-document-generated-b\" role=\"contentinfo\">\n                <section class=\"footer-body\">\n                    <p>Document generated by Confluence on Jul 12, 2023 14:01<\/p>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-atlassian\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.atlassian.com\/\">Atlassian<\/a><\/div>\n                <\/section>\n            <\/div>\n        <\/div>     \n","priority":746,"created_at":"2023-08-15T15:20:48.000000Z","updated_at":"2023-08-15T15:20:48.000000Z","created_by":{"id":6,"name":"mkh5089","slug":"mkh5089"},"updated_by":{"id":6,"name":"mkh5089","slug":"mkh5089"},"draft":false,"markdown":"","revision_count":1,"template":false,"owned_by":{"id":6,"name":"mkh5089","slug":"mkh5089"},"editor":"","tags":[]}"
Title contains numbers at the end: Infiniband  Debug tips 91226132
string(35305) "{"id":2677,"book_id":107,"chapter_id":0,"name":"Infiniband  Debug tips","slug":"infiniband-debug-tips-s6M","html":"\n\n    \n        <title id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-in\">Operations Team : Infiniband  Debug tips<\/title>\n        <link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"styles\/site.css\" type=\"text\/css\" id=\"bkmrk-\">\n        <meta id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-4\">\n                            <li class=\"first\">\n                                <span><a href=\"index.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Team_1638637.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-in-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-in-2\">\n                            Operations Team : Infiniband  Debug tips\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-norman-pa\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> Norman Patten<\/span> on Jan 11, 2021\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-getting-started-debu\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <p><br><\/p><p><strong>Getting started debugging fabric connections&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p><p><br><\/p><p>The best to start debugging an Infiniband fabric is&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">ibqueryerrors -s PortXmitWait,<\/span><span class=\"s1\">VL15Dropped &gt;error.lst<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\">options<\/p><p class=\"p1\">-s allows you to filters out informational lines and displays the errors, I usually filter&nbsp;&nbsp;<span class=\"s1\">PortXmitWait,<\/span><span class=\"s1\">VL15Dropped<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">--clear-errors, -k&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Clear error counters after read<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">--clear-counts, -K&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Clear data counters after read<\/span><\/p><p>Clearing counters after repair so you get a fresh start&nbsp;&nbsp;<span class=\"s1\">ie. ibqueryerrors -k -K<\/span><\/p><p><br><\/p><p><br><\/p><p>Types of counters, error conditions are highlighted&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p><div class=\"table-wrap\"><table style=\"\" class=\"confluenceTable\"><colgroup><col><col><col><col><\/colgroup><tbody><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">port_rcv_data<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">Total number of data octets, divided by 4 (lanes), received on all VLs. This is 64 bit counter.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortRcvData<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">port_rcv_packets<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">Total number of packets (this may include packets containing Errors. This is 64 bit counter.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortRcvPkts<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">port_multicast_rcv_packets<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">Total number of multicast packets, including multicast packets containing errors.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortMultiCastRcvPkts<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">port_unicast_rcv_packets<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">Total number of unicast packets, including unicast packets containing errors.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortUnicastRcvPkts<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">port_xmit_data<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">Total number of data octets, divided by 4 (lanes), transmitted on all VLs. This is 64 bit counter.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortXmitData<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">port_xmit_packets<\/p><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">port_xmit_packets_64<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">Total number of packets transmitted on all VLs from this port. This may include packets with errors.<\/p><p style=\"margin-left: 0.0px;\">This is 64 bit counter.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortXmitPkts<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>port_rcv_switch_relay_errors<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of packets received on the port that were discarded because they could not be forwarded by the switch relay.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortRcvSwitchRelayErrors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">port_rcv_errors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of packets containing an error that were received on the port.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortRcvErrors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>port_rcv_constraint_errors<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of packets received on the switch physical port that are discarded.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortRcvConstraintErrors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>local_link_integrity_errors<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">The number of times that the count of local physical errors exceeded the threshold specified by LocalPhyErrors.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">LocalLinkIntegrityErrors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><span style=\"color: rgb(48,48,48);\">port_xmit_wait<\/span><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">The number of ticks during which the port had data to transmit but no data was sent during the entire tick (either because of insufficient credits or because of lack of arbitration).<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortXmitWait<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">port_multicast_xmit_packets<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of multicast packets transmitted on all VLs from the port. This may include multicast packets with errors.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortMultiCastXmitPkts<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">port_unicast_xmit_packets<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of unicast packets transmitted on all VLs from the port. This may include unicast packets with errors.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortUnicastXmitPkts<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Informative<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" outbound packets discarded by the port because the port is down or congested.<\/p><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortXmitDiscards<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>port_xmit_constraint_errors<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of packets not transmitted from the switch physical port.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortXmitConstraintErrors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>port_rcv_remote_physical_errors<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of packets marked with the EBP delimiter received on the port.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">PortRcvRemotePhysicalErrors<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>symbol_error<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of minor link errors detected on one or more physical lanes.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">SymbolErrorCounter<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>VL15_dropped<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Number of incoming VL15 packets dropped due to resource limitations (e.g., lack of buffers) of the port.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">VL15Dropped<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>link_error_recovery<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of times the Port Training state machine has successfully completed the link error recovery process.<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">LinkErrorRecoveryCounter<\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Error<\/td><\/tr><tr><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><strong>link_downed<\/strong><\/td><td style=\"text-align: left;\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\">Total number of times the Port Training state machine has colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" class=\"confluenceTd\"><span>Informative<\/span><\/td><\/tr><\/tbody><\/table><\/div><p><br><\/p><p><strong>The most common errors&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p><p><br><\/p><p>port_xmit_discards - port is down or has major congestion and is dropping packets<\/p><p>symbol_error - link is getting minor CRC errors, lots of these is generally bad cable and will cause the port to reset.&nbsp;<\/p><p>VL15_dropped - this is common on a congested network and not really an issue<\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">PortRcvRemotePhysicalErrors.&nbsp;&nbsp;\u2013 generally a bad cable upstream, packet was marked with unrecoverable ECC error. This generally means there is a bad cable or HBA upstream that transmitted to this port. It doesn't&nbsp; mean the port or cable is bad.&nbsp;<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><strong>Running down bad links<\/strong><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">So you have some data from ibquerryerrors, and you need to track down a bad cable<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">First dump the fabric link info into a file&nbsp; \"<\/span><span class=\"s1\">ibnetdiscover &gt; links.lst\"<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">search links.lst for the GUID of the offending port or HBA<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">ie<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">The error from ibqueryerrors<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">GUID 0x506b4b03006a8e00 port ALL: [SymbolErrorCounter == 65535] [LinkErrorRec<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">overyCounter == 255] [LinkDownedCounter == 99] [PortRcvErrors == 630] [PortRcvRe<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">motePhysicalErrors == 27] [PortXmitDiscards == 1685] [LocalLinkIntegrityErrors =<\/span><span class=\"s1\">&nbsp;11]<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">&nbsp;&nbsp; GUID 0x506b4b03006a8e00 port 9: [SymbolErrorCounter == 65535]<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">The port 9 on switch GUID&nbsp;0x506b4b03006a8e00 looks like bad cable so we search our links.lst for the switch GUID and port 9 to find the cable connections<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">The results would be&nbsp;<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">[8] &nbsp; &nbsp; \"H-506b4b03006d7220\"[1](506b4b03006d7221) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; # \"comp-gc-0021 HCA-1\" lid 937 4xFDR<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">[10]&nbsp; &nbsp; \"H-506b4b03006d6e80\"[1](506b4b03006d6e81) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; # \"comp-gc-0023<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">The port 9 connections is missing in the list, but logic says it should be connected to&nbsp;comp-gc-0022<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><strong><span class=\"s1\">Debugging HBA's<\/span><\/strong><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">ibstatus command<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">T<\/span><span class=\"s1\">he most important information from the command is&nbsp;<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">state -active or down<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Phys state - state of the physical link, you can have a link that is up but not active without a subnetnet manager active.&nbsp;<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Rate - this should be 4x for FDR - 4 lanes at 14 Gb per lane<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><br><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><strong><span class=\"s1\">Example of what you should see in a normal state<\/span><\/strong><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Infiniband device 'mlx4_0' port 1 status:<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\"><span class=\"Apple-tab-span\"> <\/span>default gid:<span class=\"Apple-tab-span\"> <\/span> fe80:0000:0000:0000:e41d:2d03:00e1:37c1<\/span><\/p><p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\"><span class=\"Apple-tab-span\"> <\/span>base lid:<span class=\"Apple-tab-span\"> <\/span> 0x1b<\/span><\/p><p         <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Manual_18221242.html\">Operations Manual<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-du-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-du-2\">\n                            Operations Team : Dual Mount Storage Creation\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-derick-t-\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> DERICK T HAIGH<\/span>, last modified on Jan 31, 2020\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-the-following-page-w\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <p>The following page will outline the general process for an user requesting dual mount storage, starting after SLA and everything is in order:<\/p><ol><li>Create a Dual-Mount Storage task in JIRA (e.g. INFRA-3523 or INFRA-4296)<ol><li>Task should include PI's name, username, SLAID, SLA Type, Expiration date, Basic\/Standard\/High Memory Cores, Active\/Nearline storage space, allowed users, and ICS Liaison. Additionally make note if any security or unique requirements exists (nist, dbgap, IP range white-list, etc.)<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Assign to a security staff member (Matt McIntire or Ryan Gilmore) to review.<ol><li>They're review the request and if necessary reach out to the the PI to work out security requirements.<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Re-assign task to an operations team member for creation of the allocation<ol><li>Most of the allocation will follow one of the usual processes:<ol><li><a href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/IT\/Adding+an+ACI+2.0+Active+Storage+Allocation\">Adding an ACI 2.0 Active Storage Allocation<\/a><\/li><li><a href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/IT\/Adding+an+ACI+2.0+Compute+Allocation\">Adding an ACI 2.0 Compute Allocation<\/a><\/li><li><a href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/IT\/Adding+an+ACI+2.0+Archive+Storage+Allocation\">Adding an ACI 2.0 Archive Storage Allocation<\/a><\/li><li><a href=\"Adding-an-ACI-2.0-Restricted-Active-Storage-Allocation_15270062.html\">Adding an ACI 2.0 Restricted Active Storage Allocation<\/a><\/li><\/ol><\/li><li><span class=\"confluence-link\">Once the allocation is set, the following process allows for users to access the allocation using Samba<\/span><ol><li><a href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/pages\/viewpage.action?pageId=12025992\">Export Active Storage CIFS\/Samba Share<\/a><\/li><li>Remember to add the 'ICS ACI Samba Gateway' HBAC to the correct collab group using IPA<\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-information\"><p class=\"title\">Accessing a Dual Mount Allocation<\/p><span class=\"aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-info confluence-information-macro-icon\"><\/span><div class=\"confluence-information-macro-body\"><p>Typical connections to the storage via ssh are the same as for any other user. If the user connects over Samba they will need to use the gateway \\\\fsgateway.aci.ics.psu.edu\\&lt;share_name&gt;<\/p><div class=\"confluence-information-macro confluence-information-macro-warning\"><p class=\"title\">Minimum Windows Version<\/p><span class=\"aui-icon aui-icon-small aui-iconfont-error confluence-information-macro-icon\"><\/span><div class=\"confluence-information-macro-body\"><p>We now set smb encryption to mandatory which is a feature of SMB3, as SMB3 was introduced in Windows8\/Windows Server 2012 any machine running windows 7 or older should not be able to connect.<\/p><\/div><\/div><p><br><\/p><p>For Windows:<\/p><ol><li>Open up File Explorer<\/li><li>Go to \"This PC\"<\/li><li>Click the \"Computer\" tab<\/li><li>Click \"Map Network Drive\"<ol><li>For Folder enter&nbsp; \\\\<a href=\"http:\/\/fsgateway.aci.ics.psu.edu\" class=\"external-link\" rel=\"nofollow\">fsgateway.aci.ics.psu.edu<\/a>\\&lt;share_name&gt;<\/li><li>Click Finish<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>You'll be asked to enter network credentials, use&nbsp;<span class=\"nobr\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external-link\" href=\"mailto:userid@dce.psu.edu\">userid@dce.psu.edu<sup><span class=\"confluence-embedded-file-wrapper confluence-embedded-manual-size\"><img class=\"confluence-embedded-image rendericon confluence-external-resource\" draggable=\"false\" height=\"12\" width=\"13\" src=\"https:\/\/jira.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/images\/icons\/mail_small.gif\" data-image-src=\"https:\/\/jira.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/images\/icons\/mail_small.gif\"><\/span><\/sup><\/a><\/span>&nbsp;and your penn state access account password.<ol><li>Check the box to remember your credentials<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>The share should open, and will be accessible from file explorer.<\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p><p>For Linux (gnome):<\/p><ol><li>Open Files<\/li><li>Go to \"+ Other Locations\"<\/li><li>In the bottom bar there will be a place to enter \"Enterr server address...\"<ol><li>enter 'smb:\/\/fsgateway.aci.ics.psu.edu\/ops\/'<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>A window will pop up, enter the following:<ol><li>Connect As: Registered User<\/li><li>Username: &lt;userID&gt;@dce.psu.edu<\/li><li>Domain:&nbsp; SAMBA<\/li><li>Password: &lt;Penn State password&gt;<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>The share should appear on the left hand side as '&lt;share&gt; on fsgateway.aci.ics.psu.edu'<\/li><\/ol><\/div><\/div>\n                    <\/div>\n\n                                        \n                                                        <div class=\"pageSection group\">\n                        <div class=\"pageSectionHeader\">\n                            <h2 id=\"bkmrk-comments%3A\" class=\"pageSectionTitle\">Comments:<\/h2>\n                        <\/div>\n\n                        <table border=\"0\" width=\"100%\">\n                                                        <tr>\n                                <td>\n                                    <a name=\"comment-18220117\"><\/a>\n                                    <font class=\"smallfont\"><p><a class=\"confluence-userlink user-mention\" data-username=\"cjg23\" href=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\/display\/~cjg23\" data-linked-resource-id=\"558707\" data-linked-resource-version=\"1\" data-linked-resource-type=\"userinfo\" data-base-url=\"https:\/\/confluence.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\">CHARLES JOHN GILBERT<\/a>: here's the process that Derick put together for creating a Samba share. Based on our discussion with Mike, it sounds like there should be a new step after 3.a., that adds the group to the ICS-ACI Samba ACL. Correct?<\/p><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n                                        <img src=\"images\/icons\/contenttypes\/comment_16.png\" height=\"16\" width=\"16\" border=\"0\" align=\"absmiddle\">\n                                        Posted by cra5108 at Dec 07, 2017 15:21\n                                    <\/div>\n                                <\/td>\n                            <\/tr>\n                                                        <tr>\n                                <td style=\"border-top: 1px dashed #666666\">\n                                    <a name=\"comment-18223479\"><\/a>\n                                    <font class=\"smallfont\"><p>Created a collar group for export-controlled groups that need Samba access.&nbsp; This group is merely meant to carry the HBAC rule for said groups and should not have any users as direct members:<\/p><p><br><\/p><pre>[mrg225@ipa-utils01 ~]$ ipa group-add samba_exportcontrolled --desc=\"Collar group for providing SMB access to _exportcontrolled groups. No users should ever be direct members of this group.\"<br>------------------------------------<br>Added group \"samba_exportcontrolled\"<br>------------------------------------<br>  Group name: samba_exportcontrolled<br>  Description: Collar group for providing SMB access to _exportcontrolled groups. No users should ever be direct members of this group.<br>  GID: 14018<\/pre><pre>[mrg225@ipa-utils01 ~]$ ipa hbacrule-add-user ICS\\ ACI\\ Samba\\ Gateway --groups=samba_exportcontrolled<br>  Rule name: ICS ACI Samba Gateway<br>  Enabled: TRUE<br>  User Groups: aci_team, hhd_collab, commons_collab, jgn3_collab, suh21_collab, cryoem_collab, cryoem_admin, bfp2_collab, dsb10_collab, ops_collab, tgp1_collab, jxn171_collab, sam77_collab, samba_exportcontrolled<br>&nbsp; Host Groups: aci-samba-gateway<br>&nbsp; Services: samba<br>-------------------------<br>Number of members added 1<br>-------------------------<\/pre><\/font>\n                                    <div align=\"left\" class=\"smallfont\" style=\"color: #666666; width: 98%; margin-bottom: 10px;\">\n                                        <img src=\"images\/icons\/contenttypes\/comment_16.png\" height=\"16\" width=\"16\" border=\"0\" align=\"absmiddle\">\n                                        Posted by mrg225 at Aug 29, 2018 17:44\n                                    <\/div>\n                                <\/td>\n                            <\/tr>\n                                                    <\/table>\n                    <\/div>\n                                      \n                <\/div>             <\/div> \n            <div id=\"bkmrk-document-generated-b\" role=\"contentinfo\">\n                <section class=\"footer-body\">\n                    <p>Document generated by Confluence on Jul 12, 2023 14:00<\/p>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-atlassian\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.atlassian.com\/\">Atlassian<\/a><\/div>\n                <\/section>\n            <\/div>\n        <\/div>     \n","priority":748,"created_at":"2023-08-15T15:20:49.000000Z","updated_at":"2023-08-15T15:20:49.000000Z","created_by":{"id":6,"name":"mkh5089","slug":"mkh5089"},"updated_by":{"id":6,"name":"mkh5089","slug":"mkh5089"},"draft":false,"markdown":"","revision_count":1,"template":false,"owned_by":{"id":6,"name":"mkh5089","slug":"mkh5089"},"editor":"","tags":[]}"

Title contains numbers at the end: Updating Nvidia GPU drivers 124518401
string(10979) "{"id":2680,"book_id":107,"chapter_id":0,"name":"Updating Nvidia GPU drivers","slug":"updating-nvidia-gpu-drivers-kko","html":"\n\n    \n        <title id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-up\">Operations Team : Updating Nvidia GPU drivers<\/title>\n        <link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"styles\/site.css\" type=\"text\/css\" id=\"bkmrk-\">\n        <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text\/html; charset=UTF-8\" id=\"bkmrk--1\">\n    \n\n    \n        <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper\">\n            <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-1\" class=\"aui-page-panel\">\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-2\">\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-3\">\n                        <ol id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-4\">\n                            <li class=\"first\">\n                                <span><a href=\"index.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Team_1638637.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"How-to-articles_2589258.html\">How-to articles<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-up-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-up-2\">\n                            Operations Team : Updating Nvidia GPU drivers\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-gary-skou\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> Gary Skouson<\/span>, last modified by <span class=\"editor\"> DERICK T HAIGH<\/span> on Feb 18, 2022\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-the-gpu-driver-versi\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <p>The GPU driver version is defined in the puppet files used on the nodes.&nbsp; Unfortunately, you can't just update the puppet code with new versions to get updates pushed out.&nbsp; The yum commands will encounter problems and fail.&nbsp; It seems like I've had to first do a \"yum remove\" to remove the current drivers, then the puppet run should put the proper drivers in place.<\/p><h2 id=\"bkmrk-step-by-step-guide\">Step-by-step guide<\/h2><p>Here's what I've done to test things:<\/p><ol><li>I drained\/offlined one of the comp-ic nodes to test:<ol><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">From moab01<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>pbsnodes -o comp-ic-0001 -N \"GBS35 testing\"<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Login to comp-ic-0001<\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Copy some of the puppet stuff from \/opt\/puppet into \/tmp so I can run some tests without changing stuff for everyone<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>mkdir -p \/tmp\/gbs\/production\ncd \/tmp\/gbs\/production\ncp -a \/opt\/puppet\/production\/modules \/opt\/puppet\/production\/manifests \/opt\/puppet\/production\/hiera \/opt\/puppet\/production\/hiera.yaml .\nvi nvidia-driver-branch-440-cuda<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Run the standard puppet run and point it at the temporary path:<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>[root@comp-ic-0001 ~]# \/opt\/puppetlabs\/bin\/puppet apply -tvo --debug --no-storeconfigs --logdest console --hiera_config \/tmp\/gbs\/production\/hiera.yaml --environment production --modulepath \/tmp\/gbs\/production\/modules \/tmp\/gbs\/production\/manifests\/default.pp<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">Assuming everything works, we need to make the changes in the puppet&nbsp; in the puppet_masterless_control_repo:<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>$ git clone ssh:\/\/git@bitbucket.int.aci.ics.psu.edu:7999\/infra\/puppet_masterless_control_repo.git\n$ cd puppet_masterless_control_repo\n$ vi hiera\/osfamily\/RedHat-7.yaml\n$ git commit -a -m \"comment about what I did\"\n$ git push<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li>Commit the change and push it to git<\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">On some host with read-write to \/opt\/puppet you'll need to make sure to update the production puppet stuff:<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>$ ssh swst-qa.acib.qa.int.aci.ics.psu.edu\n[gbs35@swst-qa ~]$ sudo su -\nLast login: Wed Feb 16 15:43:18 EST 2022 on pts\/0\n[root@swst-qa ~]# cd \/opt\/puppet\/production\n[root@swst-qa production]# git pull<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li>Assuming that you've removed the old nvidia drivers, the next puppet run should put the proper version in place.<\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">The puppet stuff isn't going to work until we remove the existing packages from the nodes<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>$ pdsh -w comp-gc-[0001-0027,0031-0077,0081-0085],comp-clgc-[0001-0030,0080],comp-mgc-[0001-0011],comp-ic-[0001-0024] sudo yum remove -y nvidia-driver-branch-440 nvidia-driver-branch-440-cuda<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">If you want to apply the update now, you can run the stuff that's run from the daily cron script in \/etc\/cron.d\/ansible_puppet-apply.&nbsp; You can run that on all the GPU nodes with something like the pdsh yum command above.<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>\/opt\/puppetlabs\/bin\/puppet apply -tvo --no-storeconfigs --logdest syslog --hiera_config \/opt\/puppet\/production\/hiera.yaml --environment production --modulepath \/opt\/puppet\/production\/modules \/opt\/puppet\/production\/manifests\/default.pp<\/pre>\n<\/div><\/div><\/li><li><p class=\"auto-cursor-target\">You can check which nodes have the proper packages with something like:<\/p><div class=\"preformatted panel\" style=\"border-width: 1px;\"><div class=\"preformattedContent panelContent\">\n<pre>gbs35@gbs35u:~$ pdsh -w comp-gc-[0001-0027,0031-0077,0081-0085],comp-clgc-[0001-0030,0080],comp-mgc-[0001-0011],comp-ic-[0001-0024] 'rpm -qa | grep \"nvidia-driver-branch\" | grep cuda | sort' | dshbak -c \ncomp-gc-0083: string(9025) "{"id":2682,"book_id":107,"chapter_id":0,"name":"00   Operations Ideas and Wish List","slug":"00-operations-ideas-and-wish-list-UHM","html":"\n\n    \n        <title id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-00\">Operations Team : 00 - Operations Ideas and Wish List<\/title>\n        <link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"styles\/site.css\" type=\"text\/css\" id=\"bkmrk-\">\n        <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text\/html; charset=UTF-8\" id=\"bkmrk--1\">\n    \n\n    \n        <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper\">\n            <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-1\" class=\"aui-page-panel\">\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-2\">\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-3\">\n                        <ol id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-oper-4\">\n                            <li class=\"first\">\n                                <span><a href=\"index.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                    <li>\n                                <span><a href=\"Operations-Team_1638637.html\">Operations Team<\/a><\/span>\n                            <\/li>\n                                                <\/ol>\n                    <\/div>\n                    <h1 id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-00-1\" class=\"pagetitle\">\n                                                <span id=\"bkmrk-operations-team-%3A-00-2\">\n                            Operations Team : 00 - Operations Ideas and Wish List\n                        <\/span>\n                    <\/h1>\n                <\/div>\n\n                <div id=\"bkmrk-created-by-gary-skou\" class=\"view\">\n                    <div class=\"page-metadata\">\n                        \n        \n    \n    \n        \n    \n        \n        \n            Created by <span class=\"author\"> Gary Skouson<\/span>, last modified on Aug 14, 2019\n                        <\/div>\n                    <div id=\"bkmrk-this-page-is-a-place\" class=\"wiki-content group\">\n                    <p>This page is a place to keep a list of ideas for someone to work on.&nbsp; Some of them are intended to be 10-20 hour tasks that could use some help.&nbsp; Others will require some design work before we execute them.<\/p><p>Feel free to add other things to this list.<\/p><p>Feel free to clarify or add sub-bullets to these if there are other things we should think about.&nbsp; This isn't necessarily in any kind of priority order.&nbsp; Other things can be put on this list in any order you'd like.<\/p><p>As an overarching goal, I'd like to have the stuff we operate managed using good configuration management techniques.&nbsp; We should know what configurations are changed and have documentation to ensure we keep them configured as they're supposed to be.&nbsp; Ideally, we'd have things in git\/puppet\/chef\/ansible\/satellite\/etc. so that if we rebuild things they get put back the way they're supposed to be.&nbsp; I'm not sure if this is a task in and of itself, but it needs to be in the back of your mind as you work on any of the stuff we normally do.<\/p><p>For example, if we need to rebuild one of the NSD nodes, we should understand if there are any cron jobs or other files or configuration changes we needed and make sure that putting those things back in place is part of the process we use.&nbsp; We don't want to do a DDN update to the NSDs and find that things that users expect to work have stopped working for them.<\/p><p><br><\/p><h3 id=\"bkmrk-storage-stuff\">Storage Stuff<\/h3><ol><li>DataMgr nodes cluster software is very unhappy and seems to be causing GPFS issues.<\/li><li>Get capacity and inode trend data into Graphite.<\/li><li>Configure storage so we don't need to login as root to any storage systems for normal day-to-day activities<\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p><h3 id=\"bkmrk-network-stuff\">Network Stuff<\/h3><ol><li>Make a Network Diagram<ol><li>We need to understand all the networks we run and how they're connected and which ports are blocked or permitted between them<\/li><li>This is intended to be more of a \"this is what we intend\" rather than a print out of what's in the current ACL list.<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Getting Network changes into a configuration management system<ol><li>network management software (rancid, open-nms, etc.)<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>IB Network is not being monitored \/ maintained.&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p><h3 id=\"bkmrk-other-monitoring-stu\">Other Monitoring Stuff<\/h3><ol><li>Version 2 of the monitoring platform (graphite\/grafana\/ whatever)<ol><li>instructions on building it and keeping proper backups of info we need<\/li><li>Documentation on what's feeding info in that we care about and how to maintain it<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Figure out how to tell when there's likely to be \"slowness\" from a user perspective<ol><li>Monitor something and figure out how to prevent this<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Document and automate \"abusive user\" cleanup<\/li><li>What's our plan for solarwinds monitoring?<ol><li>What's useful?&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/li><li>Is Solarwinds helping us?<\/li><li>Is there somewhere else this info could be collected?<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>License server usage<ol><li>Who uses the licenses we host?<\/li><li>How much time do we spend on managing licenses?<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Generating reports from the monitoring data we collect<ol><li>Storage utilization\/allocation, compute Utilization, downtime, SLA concerns, etc.<\/li><li>How to keep things on the radar that we should be worried about?<ol><li>running out of backup tapes<\/li><li>storage dangerously low<\/li><li>number of down nodes is large<\/li><li>???<\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p><h3 id=\"bkmrk-base-hardware-manage\">Base Hardware Management<\/h3><ol><li>Password management<ol><li>iDRAC and root password management plan<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>List of hosts that we should be managing<ol><li>We should have a list of all physical hardware (compute, fileserver, networking, etc.) that we need to manage<\/li><li>We should also have a list of all \"virtual\" systems that we're supposed to operate from the operations team<br><ol><li>If there are other systems for development or QA work, it would be nice to have a list of those too.<\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Remote power control of all hosts (physical and virtual)&nbsp;<ol><li>I'd like something that understood dsh\/pdsh host naming host-[001-023]&nbsp;<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Console output logs for all hosts<\/li><li>syslog logs to files we can look at<ol><li>Not just in a database but in a text file we can tail or grep<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Configure hardware so we don't need to use a password for normal day-to-day activities<\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p><h3 id=\"bkmrk-account%2Fsla-automati\">Account\/SLA Automation<\/h3><ol><li>Group membership<ol><li>How can we automate the group membership and account creation\/audit stuff so we don't need to spend so much time on that?<\/li><\/ol><\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p><h3 id=\"bkmrk-other-stuff\">Other Stuff<\/h3><ol><li>Version 2 of the system block diagram<\/li><li><em><strong>Transition to Operations<\/strong><\/em> document for each of the systems in the block diagram<\/li><li>Documentation on how we use Satellite (on titan) and how it works with our puppet plan.<ol><li>What host collections, or subscription keys we have and how we expect to use them<\/li><li>What are the puppet \"environments\" that we care about and how do we expect them to be used?<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>What's our plan for monitoring \"fixes\" for the software we support<ol><li>Since we don't have the nodes auto-updating, when do we plan to roll out updates?<\/li><li>Which systems need to be updated.<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Group storage policies and permission options<ol><li>How can we automate the janitorial tasks that people keep asking us to perform?<\/li><\/ol><\/li><li>Getting Moab\/Torque files into git to do proper configuration management on them<\/li><li>License server plan - RHEL 5 is EOL next year.&nbsp; We need to get off of EL5<\/li><\/ol><p><br><\/p>\n                    <\/div>\n\n                                        \n                                                      \n                <\/div>
